learning_outcomes.description: Understand the theoretical background of, application of, and mathematical formulation for the following statistical procedures:1. z-test2. Repeated measures and independent groups t-tests3. Power4. ANOVA5. Correlation6. Multiple regression7. Non-parametric versions of each of the above
Write the 'Results' component of a research report.

assessments.task_description:
• The mid-semester exam will be a 90 minute invigilated, open-book exam run by UQ.
  • The exam will assess theory and application of statistical concepts covered in the lectures (Weeks 1-4) and tutorials (Weeks 2-4). Students will also need to perform calculations covered in the lectures and tutorials to answer some questions.
  • The exam is open book and you can bring in any written materials that you would like (e.g., lecture and tutorial slides, the student workbook, etc).
  • You will need a calculator for this exam. It must be a UQ approved calculator.
  • The exam will consist of multiple-choice questions only. Some multiple-choice questions will be stand-alone. Other multiple-choice questions will be components of one broader question.
  • The date for the mid-semester exam is set centrally by UQ. The exam will take place on a Saturday.
  • Tutors will hold consultations for exam feedback after all students have completed the exam (consultation times to be posted on Learn.UQ).
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This assignment will be discussed in more detail during the semester.

Assignments are to be submitted electronically via Turnitin. 

See information regarding extensions and late penalties within the School of Psychology.

Late assignments will not be accepted after marks have been released (approximately three weeks after assignments are submitted).
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments are to be submitted online via Learn.UQ/Turnitin. NOTE: You will no longer receive an automatic submission receipt from Turnitin confirming your assignment has been received. You should download a copy of the digital receipt from the Assignment Dashboard and keep this as a record.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
•  The final exam will be an in-person on campus, invigilated, closed-book exam held during the examination period and administered by the UQ Central Examinations unit.
  • The exam will assess theory and application of statistical concepts covered in all the lectures and tutorials from week 5 onwards. Students will need to perform calculations covered in the lectures and tutorials to answer some questions. Students will also be required to interpret statistical results.
  • The exam will consist of multiple-choice questions only. Some multiple-choice questions will be stand-alone. Other multiple-choice questions will be components of one broader question. A practice exam will be made available so that students can get a feel for the types of questions that will be included in the actual exam.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 1. Overview and review of Z distributions

This lecture reviews material addressed in PSYC1040 such as normal distributions and z-scores.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_title: Lecture 1. Overview and review of Z distributions
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 1. Overview and review of Z distributions This lecture reviews material addressed in PSYC1040 such as normal distributions and z-scores.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 2. Single sample tests

This lecture continues the revision of key concepts from PSYC1040 including: hypothesis-testing, single sample tests (when the POPULATION variance is known (Z test) and the POPULATION variance is not known (single sample t test).


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 2. Single sample tests This lecture continues the revision of key concepts from PSYC1040 including: hypothesis-testing, single sample tests (when the POPULATION variance is known (Z test) and the POPULATION variance is not known (single sample t test).

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 1: Fundamentals and single sample tests

Fundamentals and single sample tests


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 1: Fundamentals and single sample tests Fundamentals and single sample tests

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 3. t-tests

This lecture covers two sample tests, using the same people twice (repeated measures t-test) and two different groups (independent groups t-test). We will also cover the assumptions of t-tests.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 3. t-tests This lecture covers two sample tests, using the same people twice (repeated measures t-test) and two different groups (independent groups t-test). We will also cover the assumptions of t-tests.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 2: Two sample t tests

Two sample t tests


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 2: Two sample t tests Two sample t tests

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 4. Power and effect size

This lecture covers power and effect size.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 4. Power and effect size This lecture covers power and effect size.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 3: Power of psychological research

Power of psychological research


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 3: Power of psychological research Power of psychological research

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 5. ANOVA I (one-way independent groups)

This lecture is the first of four lectures covering the most frequently used analysis for group designs: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA). An overview of one-way ANOVA will be presented, including the calculation of the omnibus test, partitioning of variance, and the underlying structural model.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 5. ANOVA I (one-way independent groups) This lecture is the first of four lectures covering the most frequently used analysis for group designs: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA). An overview of one-way ANOVA will be presented, including the calculation of the omnibus test, partitioning of variance, and the underlying structural model.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 4: One-way ANOVA

One-way ANOVA


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 4: One-way ANOVA One-way ANOVA

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 6. ANOVA II (Follow-up tests)

This lecture continues from the calculation of the omnibus tests of the overall one-way to assess group differences using planned comparisons and post-hoc tests.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 6. ANOVA II (Follow-up tests) This lecture continues from the calculation of the omnibus tests of the overall one-way to assess group differences using planned comparisons and post-hoc tests.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 5: ANOVA - Multiple comparisons

ANOVA - Multiple comparisons

Tutorials this week will not be delivered in person. Instead tutorial instructions will be recorded and made available via Blackboard.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 5: ANOVA - Multiple comparisons ANOVA - Multiple comparisons Tutorials this week will not be delivered in person. Instead tutorial instructions will be recorded and made available via Blackboard.

learning_activities.topic: Mid-semester break
learning_activities.topic_description: Mid-semester break

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 7. ANOVA III (Repeated Measures)

This is the third lecture on ANOVA. In this lecture students will be shown how the analysis of variance can be used to test repeated time points.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 7. ANOVA III (Repeated Measures) This is the third lecture on ANOVA. In this lecture students will be shown how the analysis of variance can be used to test repeated time points.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 6: Repeated measures ANOVA

Repeated measures ANOVA


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 6: Repeated measures ANOVA Repeated measures ANOVA

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 8. ANOVA IV Factorial & Non-Parametric

This lecture is the fourth lecture on ANOVA and begins a new topic on analyses that can be used to test data that do not meet the assumptions required to use t-tests or ANOVA.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 8. ANOVA IV Factorial & Non-Parametric This lecture is the fourth lecture on ANOVA and begins a new topic on analyses that can be used to test data that do not meet the assumptions required to use t-tests or ANOVA.

Tutorial 7: Factorial ANOVA & non-parametric tests

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

This lecture will focus on the Chi-Square tests.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 10. Correlations I

This lecture introduces correlations, focusing on the calculation of r, variance accounted (r square), and non-parametric versions of r.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 11. Correlation II & Regression

In this lecture the concept of correlation (relationship between two variables) is extended to regression (using a known association to make a prediction).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

In this final lecture the concept of regression is further extended.
